project_title: VOTER REGISTRATION SYSTEM
long_description: THIS ACTIVITY SUPPORTS REFORMS IN ELECTORAL COMMISSIONS IN THE PACIFIC. IN 1997, 2000 AND 2002 THE AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL COMMISSION ORGANISED WORKSHOPS AND A PACIFIC ISLANDS, AUSTRALIA AND NEW ZEALAND PIANZEA)CONFERENCE UNDER THIS PROJECT. THE PRIMARY AIM OF THE WORKSHOPS IS TO ESTABLISH A NETWORK FOR THE EXCHANGE OF INFORMATION, EXPANSION OF KNOWLEDGE, AND TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES ON ELECTORAL ISSUES IN SOUTH PACIFIC COUNTRIES. IN 2000 AUSAID PROVIDED $150,000 TO THE AEC TO IMPLEMENT AN AUTOMATED STATE VOTER REGISTRATION SYSTEM IN POHNPEI (FSM). VOTER REGISTRATION UP TO THIS POINT HAD BEEN CONDUCTED MANUALLY LEADING TO CONSIDERABLE PROBLEMS IN THE REPORTING AND QUALITY OF INFORMATION AND LIMITED MECHANISMS TO PROTECT THE VOTING SYSTEM AGAINST MULTIPLE REGISTRATION OR OTHER METHODS OF MULTIPLE VOTING. FOLLOWING THIS ACTIVITY, DISCUSSIONS WERE HELD BETWEEN THE FSM NATIONAL ELECTORAL COMMISSIONER AND THE AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY IN POHNPEI WITH THE VIEW OF IMPLEMENTING THE SYSTEM ON A NATIONAL BASIS, WHICH IS BEING DONE IN 2002 UNDER BILATERAL FUNDIN

project_title: ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE 2004
long_description: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE ACTIVITY IS TO ASSIST INDONESIA IN ITS EFFORTS TO MOUNT A FREE, FAIR AND CREDIBLE DEMOCRATIC ELECTION IN 2004. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED THROUGH, AMONGST OTHER THINGS, STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OFTHE INDONESIAN ELECTION COMMISSION (KPU). INITIAL ASSISTANCE IN 2002/03 WILL FOCUS ON ELECTORAL ADMINISTRATOR MANAGEMENT (BRIDGE) TRAINING FOR THE KPU. THIS WILL BE THE ENTRY POINT FOR AUSTRALIA'S ASSISTANCE IN THE LEAD UP TO THE 2004 ELECTIONS. THE PROJECT WILL MOBILISE IN NOVEMBER 2002, WITH TRAINING TAKING PLACE BETWEEN FEBRUARY AND APRIL 2003 AND OVERALL COMPLETION BY JUNE 2003. THE AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL COMMISSION (AEC)WILL DELIVER THE $700,000.00 COMPONENT. THE AEC ARE CONSIDERED THE LEADING EXPERTS ON ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE IN AUSTRALIA AND ARE WELL KNOWN TO THE KPU. IT IS ENVISAGED THAT AUSAID WILL CONTINUE TO CALL UPON THE AEC'S SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE IN THE LEAD UP TO THE 2004 ELECTIONS. AUSTRALIA COMMITTED $15 MILLION TO THE 1999 ELECTION. SIMILAR LEVELS ARE BEING CONSIDERED FOR THE 2004, WHICH WILL BE THE FIRST TIME A PRESIDENT IS DIR

project_title: ELECTIONS & DEMOCRACY MONITORING 02/03
long_description: Themes: 0101 - Good Governance  Expected Impact / Long-term Results:  Strengthened electoral process and a civil society better informed about elections and democracy in Nigeria, actively participating in the post-election democratic milieux        Expected Outcomes / Medium-term Results:  1. Improved transparency and effectiveness of polling where election monitors are present, contributing to decreased opportunities for vote tampering 2. Voters better informed about issues relating to elections and the democratic process through exposure to gender-sensitive voter education material, including active participation of women and men in democracy monitoring 3. Elections analysed and monitoring reports produced with recommendations for improving the democratic process in Nigeria and lessons-learned for strengthening electoral procedures 4. Strengthened capacity of JDPC in project management, RBM, and a bolstered network of contacts        Expected Outputs / Short-term Results:  1. Effective voter education material produced, including 100,000 copies of training manual on election monitoring and voter education; and 100,000 each of posters, stickers, t-shirts, and radio and TV jingles 2. Approximately 10,000 elections and democracy monitors effectively trained, mobilized, and present during polling process 3. Elections effectively monitored in 18 states 4. Data on election results gathered and analyzed        Gender Equality Measures:  There are a number of entry points through which this project can contribute to achieving gender equality in Nigeria. Nigeria rates low, even among African nations, in the number of women elected to political positions. This is particularly disconcerting given the numbers of highly educated women in Nigeria. The bilateral desk has shared CIDA's Policy on Gender Equality with the implementing organizations and has made recommendations for consideration in project design. Two key areas to be monitored will be the number of women who took part in the training sessions and the content of the voter education material. We have asked that the project take special measures to ensure the participation of women in training sessions and that gender equality be adequately addressed in the voter education material.      Environment: No direct environmental benefits are expected from a project of this nature. Nevertheless, under democratic rule, the GON has made a strong commitment to improving environmental management. President Obasanjo created Nigeria's first Ministry of Environment, during his administration, raising the profile of this portfolio to cabinet level status. It is thus demonstrated that democratic governance has had a positive influence on environmental management in Nigeria.   Further analysis of Nigeria's environmental challenges and policies are reviewed in the CIDA Environment Strategy for Nigeria, produced by the bilateral desk. In terms of this project's relationship to the environment, we can say that based on past experience democratic governance, bolstered by competitive multiparty elections, will bode well for improved environmental management in Nigeria.

long_description: THEMES: 0101 - GOOD GOVERNANCE, 0105 - CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT  EXPECTED IMPACT / LONG-TERM RESULTS: IMPROVED PLANNING, FACILITATION AND MANAGEMENT CAPACITIES OF THE NATIONAL ELECTION COMMITTEE AND ITS PARTNERS.   EXPECTED OUTCOMES / MEDIUM-TERM RESULTS: STRENGTHEN THE PARTICIPATORY DEMOCRATIC PROCESSES IN CAMBODIA BUILD THE NATIONAL CAPACITY OF THE NEC CONTRIBUTE TO PEACEBUILDING THROUGH THE DECENTRALISATION OF GOVERNMENT IN CAMBODIA   EXPECTED OUTPUTS / SHORT-TERM RESULTS: AN EFFECTIVE AND RELIABLE SYSTEM FOR VOTER REGISTRATION. AN ACCURATE VOTER REGISTRATION LIST THAT WILL BE REUSED IN FUTURE ELECTIONS REDUCING EXPENSES. PRODUCTION OF PUBLIC EDUCATION MATERIAL CONSISTING OF POSTERS, LEAFLETS, BANNERS AND VIDEOS. MORE EFFECTIVE AND SYSTEMATIC POLITICAL PARTY REGISTRATION PROCESSES. MORE EFFECTIVE ELECTION AND EVALUATION PROCESS AND RESOURCE ALLOCATION.

project_title: AFGHANISTAN VOTER REGISTRATION
long_description: THEMES: 0101 - GOOD GOVERNANCE  EXPECTED IMPACT / LONG-TERM RESULTS: THE NATIONWIED ELECTION, PLANNED FOR JUNE 2004, WILL TAKE PLACE.  EXPECTED OUTCOMES / MEDIUM-TERM RESULTS: BOTH MALE AND FEMALE VOTERS WILL BE REGISTERED FOR THE PLANNED JUNE 2004 ELECTION.  EXPECTED OUTPUTS / SHORT-TERM RESULTS: MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT FOR THE NATION-WIDE REGISTRATION OF VOTERS IN AFGHANISTAN WILL BE SUPPLIED.  GENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: HALF OF THE 2,600 THE REGISTRATION OFFICERS WILL BE WOMEN. HALF THE VOTER REGISTRATION TEAMS (800 IN TOTAL) WILL BE WOMEN. WOMEN WILL BE REGISTERED AND WILL VOTE IN SITUATIONS WHERE ONLY WOMEN WILL BE PRESENT.

project_title: Azerbaijan Lawyers Association
long_description: To defend the political rights of voters, election monitors, and candidates during the electoral period. The Association will hold seminars and roundtables about the electoral law in Baku and eight regions. The Association will provide legal aid for voters omitted from the voter lists and for those who feel they have been unfairly denied the possibility of registering as candidates. After the elections, the Association will initiate cases on behalf of voters or candidates in districts with repor

project_title: Center for Civic Education (CCE)
long_description: To inform and educate citizens about democratic rights, political parties, and political institutions and to encourage greater public participation in the electoral process. The CCE will organize a voter registration campaign, hold civic forums to discuss critical issues, produce educational materials and newsletters, and hold a national conference to improve the accountability of political parties.

project_title: PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS                 ATE HAVING FREE AND FAIR PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS TAKE PLACE IN AFGHANISTAN IN 2005 AND TO CREATE SUSTAINABLE CAPACITY FOR NATIONAL MANAGEMENT OF FUTURE ELECTIONS.THROUGH THE PROPOSED PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS INITIATIVE, THE IAEC, JEMB, UNAMA AND VARIOUS INDIVIDUALS AND CIVIL SOCIETY GROUPS WILL: I) CONDUCT CIVIC EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN ALL PROVINCES OF THE COUNTRY; II) PROVIDE OPERATIONAL SUPPORT TO THE IAEC AND JEMB SECRETARIAT; III) DELIVER PUBLIC INFORMATION CAMPAIGNS; IV) PRINT POLLING BALLOTS AND PROCURE BALLOT BOXES AND GENERAL POLLING STATION MATERIALS; V) TRAIN POLLING STATION OFFICIALS AND VOTE COUNTING OFFICERS; VI) COLLABORATE WITH THE MINISTRY OF INTERIOR TO DEVELOP PLANS FOR ENSURING ADEQUATE ELECTION SECURITY; VII) ACCREDIT AND TRAIN ELECTION MONITORS AND OBSERVERS; VIII) DEVELOP ELECTION SECURITY ARRANGEMENTS IN COLLABORATION WITH THE INTERNATIONAL SECURITY ASSISTANCE FORCE (ISAF),  IX) TRAIN PARLIAMENTARY CANDIDATES AND POLITICAL PARTIES ON THE ELECTORAL LAW AND LEGITIMATE CAMPAIGN PROCESSES; X) ARRANGE MANAGEMENT OF POLLING STATIONS ON ELECTION DAY; AND, XII) ARRANGE COLLATION OF ALL BALLOTS IN PROVINCES AND THEIR TRANSPORTATION TO COUNTING CENTRE PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS SUPPORTEXPECTED IMPACT: RESULTS OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS OF 2005 REFLECT THE ACTIVE PARTICIPATION OF CIVIL SOCIETY AND ARE DEEMED AS BEING FREE AND FAIR BY THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY.     AFGHANI NATIONALS (MALE AND FEMALE) ABLE TO MANAGE FUTURE NATIONAL ELECTIONS.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1.  GREATER AWARENESS AMONG BOTH MEN AND WOMEN OF PARLIAMENTARY ELECTION ISSUES, PROCEDURES AND CANDIDATE PLATFORMS. 2.  A SECURITY FRAMEWORK IS PUT IN PLACE TO ENSURE VOTER TURNOUT (MALE AND FEMALE) AND THEIR PROTECTION. 3.  EFFECTIVE AND KNOWLEDGEABLE ELECTION MONITORS AND OBSERVERS WHO ARE ABLE TO ENSURE INTEGRITY OF PROCESS ON ELECTION/COUNTING DAY. 4. ELECTED AND FUNCTIONING PARLIAMENT OF AFGHANISTAN.EXPECTED OUTPUTS: OUTPUTS -- 1A.  SUFFICIENT DONOR RESOURCES MOBILIZED AND ALLOCATED RAPIDLY, EFFECTIVELY AND EFFICIENTLY TO ENABLE THE PREPARATION AND ORGANIZATION OF FREE AND FAIR ELECTIONS THROUGHOUT AFGHANISTAN 1B.  THE ELECTORAL PROCESS IS EFFECTIVELY MANAGED AND CONDUCTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS 1C.  MEN AND WOMEN PARLIAMENTARY CANDIDATES STANDING TO RUN FOR THE PARLIAMENT IN AFGHANISTAN. 1D. CONTINUATION OF THE VOTER REGISTRATION PROCESS OF AFGHANS LEFT BEHIND TO GET REGISTERED IN THE LAST VOTER REGISTRATIONE EXERCISE. 2..   VOTER INFORMATION AND CIVIC EDUCATION ARE PROVIDED TO THE AFGHAN PUBLIC (MALE AND FEMALE). 3A.  AN ENVIRONMENT OF EQUITABLE ACCESS TO MEDIA THROUGH THE SUPPORT TO THE MEDIA COMMISSION. 3B.  NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL ELECTION OBSERVATION IS FACILITATED THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY. COUNTRIES: AFGHANISTAN TIS (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: GOOD GOVERNANCE, CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT

project_title: UNDP VOTER REGISTRATION PROJECT
long_description: THE AFGHAN TRANSITIONAL ADMINISTRATION, UNDP AND UNITED NATIONS ASSISTANCE MISSION TO AFGHANISTAN (UNAMA) ARE WORKING TOGETHER IN PREPARATION FOR PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS ON OCTOBER 9, 2004, FOLLOWED BY PARLIAMENTARYELECTIONS SCHEDULED FOR SEPTEMBER 18 2005

THE AFGHAN TRANSITIONAL ADMINISTRATION, UNDP AND UNITED NATIONS ASSISTANCE MISSION TO AFGHANISTAN (UNAMA) ARE WORKING TOGETHER IN PREPARATION FOR PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS ON OCTOBER 9, 2004, FOLLOWED BY PARLIAMENTARYELECTIONS SCHEDULED FOR APRIL 2004. IN FEBRUARY 2004 AUSTRALIA PROVIDED A CONTRIBUTION OF $2 MILLION TO UNDP TO SUPPORT REGISTRATION OF AFGHANISTAN'S APPROXIMATELY 10.5 MILLION ELIGIBLE VOTERS. A FURTHER CONTRIBUTION OF $2 MILLION WAS MADE TO UNDP IN SEPTEBER 2004 IN SUPPORT OF ELECTIONS BRINGING AUSTRALIA'S TOTAL SUPPORT TO $4 MILLION. ASSISTANCE ALSO INCLUDES $2 MILLION FOR PREPARATIONS FOR THE 2005 NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS.

project_title: ELECTORAL OBSERVATION IN AMERICAS
long_description: CONTRIBUTION OF GENDER EQUALITY: THE STRONG PARTICIPATION OF  BOTH WOMEN AND MEN IN OAS EOMS HAS FURTHERED LEGITIMIZED THE MISSIONS IN THE EYES OF THE PUBLIC IN HOST COUNTRIES, INASMUCH AS THE COMPOSITION OF THE MISSIONS REFLECTS THE DEMOGRAPHIC COMPOSITION OF THE COUNTRIES OBSERVED. FURTHERMORE, IT INDIRECTLY ENCOURAGES GREATER FEMALE PARTICIPATION IN POLITICAL-ELECTORAL ISSUES THROUGH THE DEMONSTRATION EFFECT. GREATER PARTICIPATION OF WOMEN IN THE UNDERTAKING OF EOMS BOTH AT HEADQUARTERS AND IN THE FIELD HAS ALSO INCREASED SENSITIVITY OF ALL MISSION PARTICIPANTS TO GENDER EQUITY ISSUES. FOR EXAMPLE, AS PART AND PARCEL OF THE EVALUATIONS MADE BY OAS EOMS, THE RATE OF FEMALE PARTICIPATION AS CANDIDATES AND AS A PERCENTAGE OF REGISTERED AND ACTUAL VOTERS IS FREQUENTLY RECORDED AND ANALYZED, FOR THE PURPOSE OF FORMULATING SPECIFIC POLICY OR PROCEDURAL RECOMMENDATIONS ON THIS ISSUE, IF REQUIRED.ENVIRONMENT: CEAA IS NOT APPLICABLEEXPECTED IMPACT: ENABLE THE ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES TO DISCHARGE, IN AN EFFICIENT AND TIMELY BASIS, ITS MANDATES AS ENSHRINED IN BOTH THE CHARTER OF THE ORGANIZATION AND IN THE INTER-AMERICAN DEMOCRATIC CHARTER  - IN PARTICULAR, TO  STRENGTHEN THE PEACE AND SECURITY OF THE CONTINENT;;  AND TO PROMOTE AND CONSOLIDATE REPRESENTATIVE DEMOCRACY, WITH DUE RESPECT FOR THE PRINCIPLE OF NONINTERVENTION.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: SUPPORTING TECHNICAL ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE, ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSIONS AND TECHNICAL AND POLITICAL SUPPORT TO MEMBER STATES IN THEIR LONG-TERM POLITICAL REFORM AND DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTION-BUILDING EFFORTS.   STRENGTHEN ELECTORAL PROCESSES IN THE HEMISPHERE, THROUGH TECHNICAL ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE AND ELECTORAL OBSERVATION MISSIONSEXPECTED OUTPUTS: INTEGRITY, IMPARTIALITY, AND RELIABILITY OF ELECTIONS; REINFORCE CREDIBILITY OF DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTIONS SUPPORT FOR THE RULE OF LAW AND ANTI-CORRUPTION MEASURESGENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: GENDER ISSUES WILL BE ADDRESSED IN THE INDIVIDUAL PROJECT ACTIVITIES TO BE FUNDED (REQUESTS)COUNTRIES: NICARAGUA (20%), BOLIVIA (15%), GUYANA (15%), PERU (15%), VENEZUELA REP B (11%), COLOMBIA (10%), HONDURAS (10%), DOMINICAN REP. project_title: POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS VIA CANADEM
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS VIA CANADEM  THE CANADEM ROSTER WILL RECRUIT, EQUIP, BRIEF, INSURE, AND DEPLOY 25 RETIRED CANADIAN POLICE TO BE ATTACHED TO UN MINUSTAH TO SERVE AS POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS TO: · SERVE AS A LINK BETWEEN THE HNP AND THE MILITARY/FPU, D-JESC AND CIVPOL FOR PLANNING, AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACCORDING TO THE ELECTIONS SECURITY OPERATIONAL PLAN; · LIAISE BETWEEN THE COMMISSAR OF THE LOCAL HNP STATIONS, CIVPOL, MILITARY/FPU, D-JESC, ETC.; · ASSIST AND MENTOR THE HNP WITH OPERATIONAL PLANNING, RISK ASSESSMENTS AND SECURITY IMPLEMENTATION WITH A VIEW TOWARDS HNP INCREASING THEIR LEVEL OF PARTICIPATION IN THE ELECTION PROCESS. EXPECTED IMPACT: THIS INITIATIVE AIMS AT SUPPORTING A POSITIVE OUTCOME OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS IN ORDER TO HAVE AN ELECTED GOVERNMENT THAT HAS THE SUPPORT OF THE POPULATION AND THE RECOGNITION OF THE INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: . MEDIUM TERM RESULTS   · PROVIDE GREATER LOCAL SOCIAL STABILITY THROUGH ASSISTANCE TO THE HAITIAN NATIONAL POLICE. · PROVIDE CANADIAN COMPONENTS TO BOLSTER UN MINUSTAH CIVPOL. · PROVIDE ACCESS FOR ADDITIONAL CANADIAN PARTICIPATION IN HAITI. · PROVIDE LESSONS LEARNED FOR FUTURE CANADIAN EMERGENCY DEPLOYMENTS. · ENHANCE CANADIAN POLICE AND SECURITY NETWORKS. EXPECTED OUTPUTS: . OUTPUTS/SHORT TERM RESULTS · CANADEM POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS (PTAS) ARRIVE IN HAITI AND ARE IN TURN ASSIGNED TO REGIONAL POSTS. WHEN IN HAITI THESE PTAS WILL BE UNDER THE OPERATIONAL MANAGEMENT AND SUPERVISION OF UN MINUSTAH · HNP ARE TRAINED AND MENTORED BY CANADEM POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS. · UN CIVPOL ARE ASSISTED BY CANADEM POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS IN OTHER AREAS AS REQUIRED. · FAC RECEIVES REGULAR FIELD UPDATES FROM CANADEM POLICE TECHNICAL ADVISORS ON THE PROGRESS WITHIN UN MINUSTAH. COUNTRIES: HAITI (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: PEACE AND SECURITY

project_title: OSCE ELECTIONS AND GOVERNANCE
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: OSCE ELECTIONS AND GOVERNANCE: THE  PROJECT RESPONDS TO SPECIFIC REQUESTS FROM THE GOVERNMENT OF UKRAINE FOR ASSISTANCE IN ADDRESSING: WEAKNESSES IN ELECTION LEGISLATION AND ADMINISTRATION IDENTIFIED BY THE OFFICE FOR DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTIONS AND HUMAN RIGHTS (ODIHR) AND OTHER ELECTION OBSERVERS FOLLOWING THE 2002 PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS AND 2004 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS; LIMITED OPPORTUNITIES IN UKRAINE FOR PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN POLICY MAKING; LOW PARTICIPATION IN DECISION-MAKING BY WOMEN AND YOUTH; HIGH LEVELS OF CORRUPTION; AND LIMITED ACCESS TO RELIABLE INFORMATION ABOUT GOVERNMENT SERVICES AND POLICY.CONTRIBUTION OF GENDER EQUALITY: CONDUCTED 20 TRAINING SESSIONS AND A CONFERENCE FOR POLITICAL PARTIES AND MPS ON THE IMPORTANCE OF INCREASING REPRESENTATION OF WOMEN AND HOW TO INCLUDE GENDER ISSUES IN THE LEGISLATIVE PROCESS; CONDUCTED 20 SEMINARS FOR 400 JOURNALISTS ON GENDER ISSUES IN ELECTION REPORTING; CONDUCTED 4 SEMINARS FOR 135 YOUTH ON DEMOCRATIC PRACTICES AND LEADERSHIP.EXPECTED IMPACT: 1. DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTIONS AND PRACTICES IN UKRAINE ARE ENHANCED. 2. INCREASED REPRESENTATION OF WOMEN IN DECISION-MAKING POSITIONS IN GOVERNMENT.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1. ENHANCED CAPABILITY OF THE CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSION TO ADMINISTER TRANSPARENT AND FAIR ELECTIONS. 2. INCREASED PUBLIC PARTICIPATION IN DECISION-MAKING ON CERTAIN KEY ISSUES. 3. INCREASED CAPACITY OF WOMEN AND YOUTH TO PARTICIPATE IN DECISION-MAKING. 4. IMPROVED AWARENESS OF GOVERNMENT STRUCTURES AND SERVICES AMONG UKRAINIAN MEN, WOMEN AND YOUTH. 5. IMPROVED PUBLIC ACCESS TO INFORMATION VIA THE MEDIA.EXPECTED OUTPUTS: THE PROJECT WILL BE MANAGED AT THE OUTCOME LEVEL.GENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: THE PROJECT WILL SPECIFICALLY TARGET WOMEN'S ROLES IN DECISION-MAKING THROUGH: 1. A NATION-WIDE AWARENESS CAMPAIGN, FOCUSING ON INCREASING WOMEN'S REPRESENTATION IN ELECTED BODIES AND PARTICIPATION IN ELECTIONS. 2. SUPPORT FOR NETWORKING OF WOMEN'S ASSOCIATIONS, PROFESSIONAL CLUBS AND POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS. 3. PROVISION OF TRAINING IN AREAS SUCH AS CAMPAIGNING, MANAGEMENT, FUNDRAISING, MEDIA, LOBBYING, AND NETWORKING FOR WOMEN WHO ARE IDENTIFIED AS LEADERS IN CIVIL SOCIETY, BUSINESS AND GOVERNMENT.COUNTRIES: UKRAINE (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (50%), 015140 (20%), 015150 (20%), 015163 (10%)  THEMES: GOOD GOVERNANCE

project_title: ELECTORAL COMMISSION ISP
long_description: The management of elections in PNG presents unique challenges in areas such as security, recruitment, training, mobile polling, voter education and the establishment and maintenance of the electoral roll.  The PNG Electoral Commission (PNGEC) is currentl

THE MANAGEMENT OF ELECTIONS IN PNG PRESENTS UNIQUE CHALLENGES IN AREAS SUCH AS SECURITY, RECRUITMENT, TRAINING, MOBILE POLLING, VOTER EDUCATION AND THE ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF THE ELECTORAL ROLL. THE PNGELECTORAL COMMISSION (PNGEC) IS CURRENTLY EXPERIENCING CONSIDERABLE PROBLEMS IN ITS OPERATIONS AND CAPACITIES. BREAKDOWNS IN PROCEDURES AND PROCESSES IN THE LAST ELECTIONS IN DECEMBER 1997 HAVE LED TO SIX SUBSEQUENT BY-ELECTIONS. THE PROJECT DESIGN, COMPLETED IN EARLY FEBRUARY 2000, OUTLINES THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT AS STRENGTHENING THE PNGEC'S CAPACITY TO MANAGE AND RUN ELECTIONS AND THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM, TO IMPROVE THE INTEGRITY OF THE ELECTORAL ROLL, AND TO HEIGHTEN COMMUNITY AWARENESS OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE AN ON-LINE CONTINUOUS ENROLMENT SYSTEM, IMPROVING TRAINING AND AUDIT, AND THE INTRODUCTION OF A PUBLIC AWARENESS MODULE TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS IN THE COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO ENABLE PNGEC TO ACCESS TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF ANY POLICY ISSUES SUC

THE PROJECT WILL MOBILISE IN NOVEMBER 2002, WITH TRAINING TAKING PLACE BETWEEN FEBRUARY AND APRIL 2003 AND OVERALL COMPLETION BY JUNE 2003. THE AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL COMMISSION (AEC)WILL DELIVER THE $700,000.00 COMPONENT. THE AEC ARE CONSIDERED THE LEADING EXPERTS ON ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE IN AUSTRALIA AND ARE WELL KNOWN TO THE KPU. IT IS ENVISAGED THAT AUSAID WILL CONTINUE TO CALL UPON THE AEC'S SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE IN THE LEAD UP TO THE 2004 ELECTIONS. AUSTRALIA COMMITTED $15 MILLION TO THE 1999 ELECTION. project_title: ELECTIONS & DEMOCRACY MONITORING 02/03
long_description: Themes: 0101 - Good Governance  Expected Impact / Long-term Results:  Strengthened electoral process and a civil society better informed about elections and democracy in Nigeria, actively participating in the post-election democratic milieux        Expected Outcomes / Medium-term Results:  1. Improved transparency and effectiveness of polling where election monitors are present, contributing to decreased opportunities for vote tampering 2. Voters better informed about issues relating to elections and the democratic process through exposure to gender-sensitive voter education material, including active participation of women and men in democracy monitoring 3. Elections analysed and monitoring reports produced with recommendations for improving the democratic process in Nigeria and lessons-learned for strengthening electoral procedures 4. Strengthened capacity of JDPC in project management, RBM, and a bolstered network of contacts        Expected Outputs / Short-term Results:  1. Effective voter education material produced, including 100,000 copies of training manual on election monitoring and voter education; and 100,000 each of posters, stickers, t-shirts, and radio and TV jingles 2. Approximately 10,000 elections and democracy monitors effectively trained, mobilized, and present during polling process 3. Elections effectively monitored in 18 states 4. Data on election results gathered and analyzed        Gender Equality Measures:  There are a number of entry points through which this project can contribute to achieving gender equality in Nigeria. Nigeria rates low, even among African nations, in the number of women elected to political positions. This is particularly disconcerting given the numbers of highly educated women in Nigeria. The bilateral desk has shared CIDA's Policy on Gender Equality with the implementing organizations and has made recommendations for consideration in project design. Two key areas to be monitored will be the number of women who took part in the training sessions and the content of the voter education material. We have asked that the project take special measures to ensure the participation of women in training sessions and that gender equality be adequately addressed in the voter education material.      Environment: No direct environmental benefits are expected from a project of this nature. Nevertheless, under democratic rule, the GON has made a strong commitment to improving environmental management. President Obasanjo created Nigeria's first Ministry of Environment, during his administration, raising the profile of this portfolio to cabinet level status. It is thus demonstrated that democratic governance has had a positive influence on environmental management in Nigeria.   Further analysis of Nigeria's environmental challenges and policies are reviewed in the CIDA Environment Strategy for Nigeria, produced by the bilateral desk. In terms of this project's relationship to the environment, we can say that based on past experience democratic governance, bolstered by competitive multiparty elections, will bode well for improved environmental management in Nigeria.

project_title: EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION IN ACEH
short_description: EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION IN ACEH
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: CANADA SUPPORTED THE EUROPEAN UNION (EU) ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE DECEMBER 11TH, 2006, GUBERNATIONAL (PROVINCIAL/STATE/GOVERNOR) ELECTIONS OF ACEH, INDONESIA, THROUGH THE DEPLOYMENT OF CANADIAN ELECTION OBSERVERS. CANADA CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR DEMOCRATIC PROCESS IN ACEH THROUGH SUPPORT TO THE FOLLOW-UP EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE SECOND ROUND ELECTIONS ON MARCH 4TH, 2007.   THE DECEMBER 26, 2004 EARTHQUAKE AND TSUNAMI RESULTED IN SEVERE LOSS OF LIFE AND MASSIVE DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY AND DAMAGE IN ACEH, INDONESIA. IN TOTAL, FOURTEEN DISTRICTS IN ACEH PROVINCE, AS WELL AS A NUMBER OF SMALL ISLANDS THAT FORM PART OF THE PROVINCE OF NORTH SUMATRA, WERE DEVASTATED BY THE TSUNAMI. APPROXIMATELY 167,000 PEOPLE ARE KNOWN TO HAVE DIED IN ACEH AND NORTH SUMATRA. IN ADDITION, OVER 500,000 WERE DISPLACED IN ACEH ALONE. APPROXIMATELY ONE MILLION PEOPLE LOST THEIR PRIMARY SOURCE OF INCOME (PARTICULARLY IN THE AGRICULTURE AND FISHERIES SECTORS) AND TOTAL ECONOMIC LOSSES ARE ESTIMATED AT US $4 TO $5 BILLION, A SUM EQUIVALENT TO 97% OF ACEH'S GDP.   PRIOR TO THE TSUNAMI HITTING THE SHORES OF ACEH, THIRTY YEARS OF VIOLENT CONFLICT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF INDONESIA (GOI) AND THE FREE ACEH MOVEMENT (GAM) HAD ALREADY DEVASTATED LARGE PARTS OF ACEH AND CLAIMED OVER 15,000 LIVES.   ON AUGUST 15TH, 2005, THE GOI AND THE GAM SIGNED A MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU) SIGNIFYING AN END TO THE BRUTAL CONFLICT. TO DATE, THE MOU HAS EXCEEDED EXPECTATIONS. MANY ANALYSTS BELIEVE THAT THE 2004 TSUNAMI ACTED AS A CATALYST TO ENCOURAGE THE CONFLICTING PARTIES TOWARDS PEACE.   THE GUBERNATORIAL AND DISTRICT ELECTIONS IN ACEH PROVINCE, INDONESIA, IN DECEMBER, WERE THE FIRST OF THEIR KIND, AND ARE A KEY ASPECT OF THE MOU. THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 2.6 MILLION ELIGIBLE ACEHNESSE VOTERS.   INDONESIA IS ONE OF CANADA'S KEY DEVELOPMENT PARTNERS, AND A MAJOR RECIPIENT OF TSUNAMI ASSISTANCE. IN RESPONSE TO THE TSUNAMI, CIDA APPROVED AND FULLY DISBURSED APPROXIMATELY $53 MILLION IN SHORT-TERM RELIEF PROJECTS FOR ACEH AND NIAS. CIDA ALSO PROVIDED $41.2 MILLION IN RESPONSE TO THE UN FLASH APPEAL, SOME OF WHICH WOULD HAVE BEEN DISBURSED IN INDONESIA. IN ORDER TO MEET THE LONG-TERM NEEDS OF TSUNAMI SURVIVORS, APPROXIMATELY $146 MILLION OF CANADA'S $425 MILLION PLEDGE WILL BE PROVIDED TO ACEH AND NIAS FOR RECONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES.   CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE TO ACEH AND NIAS IS GUIDED BY ITS RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY, WHICH WAS DESIGNED TO COMPLIMENT THE GOVERNMENT OF INDONESIA'S MASTER PLAN FOR RECONSTRUCTION. CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY FOR ACEH AND NIAS HAS TWO MAIN THRUSTS: (1) REBUILDING AND STRENGTHENING THE SYSTEM OF LOCAL GOVERNANCE AND (2) RESTORING LIVELIHOODS. IN ADDITION, THE RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY ENSURES THAT ENVIRONMENT, GENDER AND CONFLICT-SENSITIVITY ARE INCORPORATED AS CROSS-CUTTING THEMES. SINCE THE PROPOSED INITIATIVE SUPPORTS LOCAL GOVERNANCE IN THE FORM OF ELECTION SUPPORT, IT IS COMPLIMENTARY TO CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY.EXPECTED IMPACT: A PERMANENTLY ESTABLISHED INDEPENDENT ELECTORAL MANAGEMENT BODY AND CONTINUED PEACE IN ACEH.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RECOGNIZED AND ACCEPTED ASSESSMENT OF THE ACEH 2006 LOCAL ELECTORAL PROCESSEXPECTED OUTPUTS: IMPROVED ABILITY OF ACEH CITIZENS, BOTH MEN AND WOMEN, TO PARTICIPATE IN ACEH'S 2006 LOCAL ELECTIONS IMPROVED ENABLING ENVIRONMENT FOR CIVIL SOCIETY TO HOLD POLITICAL ACTORS ACCOUNTABLE. AN INDEPENDENT AND IMPARTIAL OBSERVATION OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS IN ACEHCOUNTRIES: INDONESIA (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: CANADA CORPS

project_title: Support for the presidential elections
long_description: This project supports the Government in its endeavours to act as a strengthened democracy through a free and fair election process, and will contribute towards respect for transparency and democratic principles in the conduct of the Presidential elections of 3rd December 2006. The Norwegian support will contribute towards (a) reinforcement of capacities of the main three entities involved in the organising of the elections, i.e.:  Ministère de l'Intérieur et de la Réforme Administrative (MIRA), Haute Cour Constitutionelle (HCC), Conseil National Electoral (CNE); (b) enabling these actors to plan and implement a free and fair election process; (c) increase transparency in the management of national computerised electoral list; (d) facilitate policy dialogue  and circulation of information and (e) empowering women in electorate administration.

project_title: Gender and Governance Programme - UNIFEM
long_description: The Goal of the GGP is: Gender equity and equality in Kenyan improved. Vision: Towards 50:50 Women and Men Governing Together. Purpose: Increased women participation in democratic governance and improved gender responsive systems, structures and institutions for good governance and gender equity. UNIFEM Kenya is the Prog.Fin.Management Agent.  Acitivities includes ways of strengthening women candidates in the run up to the general elections in 2007.

project_title: GENERAL SUPPORT NATIONAL ELECTIONS GY 06
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: THE OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE HOLDING OF FREE AND FAIR ELECTIONS THAT ARE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GUYANA CONSTITUTION AND OTHER RELEVANT LAWS OF GUYANA, WHICH EMBRACE THE INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS, AS ARTICULATED BY THE VARIOUS UN DECLARATIONS, COVENANTS, CONVENTIONS, RESOLUTIONS AND REPORTS, INCLUDING THE ORGANISATION OF THE AMERICAN STATES (OAS) INTER-AMERICAN DEMOCRATIC CHARTER.  THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO STRENGTHEN ON A SUSTAINABLE BASIS, KEY ELECTORAL PROCESSES AND INSTITUTIONAL STRUCTURES, SO THESE  ELECTIONS IN GUYANA CAN CONTINUE TO BE FREE, FAIR AND TRANSPARENT, AND ACCESSIBLE TO ALL ELIGIBLE VOTERS IN GUYANA.EXPECTED IMPACT: THE HOLDING OF FREE AND FAIR ELECTIONS THAT ARE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE CONSTITUTION AND OTHER RELEVANT LAWS OF GUYANA, WHICH EMBRACE THE INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS, AS ARTICULATED BY VARIOUS UN DECLARATIONS AND DOCUMENTS.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1.   INCREASED CREDIBILITY FOR THE ELECTORAL PROCESS AND RELATED DEMOCRACY OUTCOMES; 2. AN IMPROVED ELECTORAL SYSTEM IN WHICH THE ELECTORATE CAN HAVE GREATER CONFIDENCE THAT THE OUTCOME WILL BE FREE AND FAIR AND                      T RULY REFLECT THEIR WISHES. EXPECTED OUTPUTS: THE MAIN EXPECTED RESULTS OF THE PROGRAMME ARE:   THE ELECTION RESULTS ARE ACCEPTED BY ALL POLITICAL PARTIES, AS WELL BY WIDER CIVIL SOCIETY; AFTER A TIMELY ANNOUNCEMENT OF THE RESULTS FOLLOWING A FREE, FAIR AND VIOLENCE-FREE ELECTION CAMPAIGN; IMPROVED QUALITY, EFFECTIVENESS AND EFFICIENCY OF THE ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE ELECTIONS BY THE ELECTORAL AUTHORITIES, WITH SPECIFIC FOCUS ON SUSTAINABLE IMPROVEMENT OF THE ELECTORAL REGISTER, AND THE TIMELINESSESS OF ANNOUNCING THE RESULTS; SIGNIFICANT AWARENESS AND PEACEFUL PARTICIPATION OF THE ELECTORATE IN THE ELECTIONS AND RELATED GOVERNANCE AREAS; ENHANCED CAPACITY OF NGO'S AND CBO'S TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEMOCRATIC PROCESS INCLUDING THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CIVIC EDUCATION PROGRAMS.GENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: CIDA WILL ENCOURAGE UNDP TO WORK WITH GECOM TO ENSURE BOTH MALE AND FEMALE VOTERS IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS HAVE ACCESS TO REGISTRATION AND, PUBLIC AWARENESS AND CIVIC EDUCATION ACTIVITIES. CIDA WILL ALSO REQUEST THAT MONITORING INDICATORS FOR PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE DISAGGREGATED BY SEX WHERE APPROPRIATE. COUNTRIES: GUYANA (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: GOOD GOVERNANCE

project_title: ELECTORAL OBSERVATION IN AMERICAS
long_description: CONTRIBUTION OF GENDER EQUALITY: THE STRONG PARTICIPATION OF  BOTH WOMEN AND MEN IN OAS EOMS HAS FURTHERED LEGITIMIZED THE MISSIONS IN THE EYES OF THE PUBLIC IN HOST COUNTRIES, INASMUCH AS THE COMPOSITION OF THE MISSIONS REFLECTS THE DEMOGRAPHIC COMPOSITION OF THE COUNTRIES OBSERVED. FURTHERMORE, IT INDIRECTLY ENCOURAGES GREATER FEMALE PARTICIPATION IN POLITICAL-ELECTORAL ISSUES THROUGH THE DEMONSTRATION EFFECT. GREATER PARTICIPATION OF WOMEN IN THE UNDERTAKING OF EOMS BOTH AT HEADQUARTERS AND IN THE FIELD HAS ALSO INCREASED SENSITIVITY OF ALL MISSION PARTICIPANTS TO GENDER EQUITY ISSUES. FOR EXAMPLE, AS PART AND PARCEL OF THE EVALUATIONS MADE BY OAS EOMS, THE RATE OF FEMALE PARTICIPATION AS CANDIDATES AND AS A PERCENTAGE OF REGISTERED AND ACTUAL VOTERS IS FREQUENTLY RECORDED AND ANALYZED, FOR THE PURPOSE OF FORMULATING SPECIFIC POLICY OR PROCEDURAL RECOMMENDATIONS ON THIS ISSUE, IF REQUIRED.ENVIRONMENT: CEAA IS NOT APPLICABLEEXPECTED IMPACT: ENABLE THE ORGANIZATION OF AMERICAN STATES TO DISCHARGE, IN AN EFFICIENT AND TIMELY BASIS, ITS MANDATES AS ENSHRINED IN BOTH THE CHARTER OF THE ORGANIZATION AND IN THE INTER-AMERICAN DEMOCRATIC CHARTER  - IN PARTICULAR, TO  STRENGTHEN THE PEACE AND SECURITY OF THE CONTINENT;;  AND TO PROMOTE AND CONSOLIDATE REPRESENTATIVE DEMOCRACY, WITH DUE RESPECT FOR THE PRINCIPLE OF NONINTERVENTION.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: SUPPORTING TECHNICAL ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE, ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSIONS AND TECHNICAL AND POLITICAL SUPPORT TO MEMBER STATES IN THEIR LONG-TERM POLITICAL REFORM AND DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTION-BUILDING EFFORTS.   STRENGTHEN ELECTORAL PROCESSES IN THE HEMISPHERE, THROUGH TECHNICAL ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE AND ELECTORAL OBSERVATION MISSIONSEXPECTED OUTPUTS: INTEGRITY, IMPARTIALITY, AND RELIABILITY OF ELECTIONS; REINFORCE CREDIBILITY OF DEMOCRATIC INSTITUTIONS SUPPORT FOR THE RULE OF LAW AND ANTI-CORRUPTION MEASURESGENDER EQUALITY MEASURES: GENDER ISSUES WILL BE ADDRESSED IN THE INDIVIDUAL PROJECT ACTIVITIES TO BE FUNDED (REQUESTS)COUNTRIES: NICARAGUA (20%), BOLIVIA (15%), GUYANA (15%), PERU (15%), VENEZUELA REP B (11%), COLOMBIA (10%), HONDURAS (10%), DOMINICAN REP. (2%), EL SALVADOR (2%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: GOOD GOVERNANCE, CANADA CORPS

project_title: OSCE ELECTION OBSERVATION - SERBIA -001
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: OSCE ELECTION OBSERVATION - SERBIA -001   CIDA SUPPORTED THE DEPLOYMENT OF 2 CANADIAN LONG TERM OBSERVERS AND 5 SHORT TERM OBSERVERS TO THE ORGANIZATION FOR SECURITY AND COOPERATION IN EUROPE (OSCE)'S ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS OF SERBIA ON JANUARY 21ST, 2007. CANADIAN FUNDS WERE USED TO COVER THE LOGISTICS OF DEPLOYING THESE OBSERVERS. THE EXTENT OF THEIR ACTIVITES WAS TRAVELLING TO SERBIA, A SMALL AMOUNT OF TRAVELING WITHIN THE COUNTRY, AND RETURNING HOME. WHILE IN SERBIA, THESE OBSERVERS ASSESSED THE EXTENT TO WHICH THE ELECTION PROCESS TOOK PLACE IN ADHERENCE WITH DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL LAW. THEIR OBSERVATIONS CONTRIBUTED TO THE OSCE'S FINAL REPORT ON THE ELECTION.EXPECTED IMPACT: A PERMANENTLY ESTABLISHED INDEPENDENT ELECTORAL MANAGEMENT BODY.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RECOGNIZED AND ACCEPTED ASSESSMENT OF THE SERBIAN 2007 PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS.EXPECTED OUTPUTS: IMPROVED ABILITY OF SERBIAN CITIZENS, BOTH MEN AND WOMEN, TO PARTICIPATE IN SERBIA'S 2007 PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS. project_title: OSCE Election Observation - Armenia
long_description: Project Description: OSCE Election Observation - Armenia Parliamentary Election 2007   On February 23rd, 2007, the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) sent out its Note Verbale requesting member states to contribute up to ten percent (10%) of its upcoming mission to the Parliamentary elections of Armenia, set to occur on May 12th, 2007. The mission will be composed of 24 Long Term Observes and 300 Short Term Observers. Canada wishes to send two (2) long-term observers and up to six (6 ) short -term observer to this election. During their stay, the LTOs will observe numerous parts of the election, including voter identification and registration, the extent and effectiveness of civic and voter education, political rallies and other relevant campaign activities, election administration, participation of women and national minorities in the election process, among other tasks. The STOs will be present for election day and the time period immediately bracketing it, and will witness the vote and the count..   The extent of the STO and LTO activites is travelling to Armenia, a small amount of traveling within the country, and returning home., which have minimal impact on the environment OSCE Election Observation - Armenia Parliamentary Election 2007   On February 23rd, 2007, the Organization of Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) sent out its Note Verbale requesting member states to contribute up to ten percent (10%) of its upcoming mission to the Parliamentary elections of Armenia, set to occur on May 12th, 2007. The mission will be composed of 24 Long Term Observes and 300 Short Term Observers. Canada wishes to send two (2) long-term observers and up to six (6 ) short -term observer to this election. During their stay, the LTOs will observe numerous parts of the election, including voter identification and registration, the extent and effectiveness of civic and voter education, political rallies and other relevant campaign activities, election administration, participation of women and national minorities in the election process, among other tasks. The STOs will be present for election day and the time period immediately bracketing it, and will witness the vote and the count..   The extent of the STO and LTO activites is travelling to Armenia, a small amount of traveling within the country, and returning home., which have minimal impact on the environmentExpected Impact: A permanently established independent electoral management body.Expected Outcomes: Recognized and accepted assessment of the Armenia 2007 Parliamentary Electoral Process.Expected Outputs: To support a free, fair and transparent electoral process in Armenia by providing support through the OSCE observation missionCountries: Armenia (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Canada Corps

project_title: Enhancing Legal & Electoral Capacity
long_description: Project Description: The project seeks to enhance national ownership over the electoral process by building the institutional capacity of the IEC, so that it may lead the organization and management of future democratic elections, such as the upcoming Presidential elections of 2009. In implementing this project, UNDP will work closely with the Ministries of Interior (MOI), Women's Affairs (MOWA), and UNAMA. The project will mainly involve the deployment of international advisors to each IEC Secretariat department. The advisors will mentor each Department Head on day-to-day operations and build capacity through on-the-job coaching.   The joint civil and voter registry will reviewed, and lessons learned from its development will be col-lated and fed into the design and planning of a nationwide joint voter/civil registry exercise which will issue a national identification document (ID) for all citizens above fifteen years of age. The national ID will link the voters to individual polling stations preventing the risk of issuing multiple voter registration cards to a single voter. It will also be used to establish polling stations in locations that will improve the accessibility of the voters.   The Voter and Civil Registration pilot project will strive to link up with other government projects im-plemented by the Ministry of Transport and Ministry of Interior, which are also based on extending and systematizing the government's administrative control at the sub-national level through the use of com-mon processes and documents.   To implement this project, UNDP will coordinate closely with other similar projects by Asia (TAF) Foundation and the International Foundation for Electoral Systems (IFES), both funded by USAID in order to maximize impact and avoid duplication. The duration of this project will be three years. Countries: Afghanistan TIS (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Capacity Development

project_title: EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION IN ACEH
short_description: EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION IN ACEH
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: CANADA SUPPORTED THE EUROPEAN UNION (EU) ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE DECEMBER 11TH, 2006, GUBERNATIONAL (PROVINCIAL/STATE/GOVERNOR) ELECTIONS OF ACEH, INDONESIA, THROUGH THE DEPLOYMENT OF CANADIAN ELECTION OBSERVERS. CANADA CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR DEMOCRATIC PROCESS IN ACEH THROUGH SUPPORT TO THE FOLLOW-UP EU ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE SECOND ROUND ELECTIONS ON MARCH 4TH, 2007.   THE DECEMBER 26, 2004 EARTHQUAKE AND TSUNAMI RESULTED IN SEVERE LOSS OF LIFE AND MASSIVE DESTRUCTION OF PROPERTY AND DAMAGE IN ACEH, INDONESIA. IN TOTAL, FOURTEEN DISTRICTS IN ACEH PROVINCE, AS WELL AS A NUMBER OF SMALL ISLANDS THAT FORM PART OF THE PROVINCE OF NORTH SUMATRA, WERE DEVASTATED BY THE TSUNAMI. APPROXIMATELY 167,000 PEOPLE ARE KNOWN TO HAVE DIED IN ACEH AND NORTH SUMATRA. IN ADDITION, OVER 500,000 WERE DISPLACED IN ACEH ALONE. APPROXIMATELY ONE MILLION PEOPLE LOST THEIR PRIMARY SOURCE OF INCOME (PARTICULARLY IN THE AGRICULTURE AND FISHERIES SECTORS) AND TOTAL ECONOMIC LOSSES ARE ESTIMATED AT US $4 TO $5 BILLION, A SUM EQUIVALENT TO 97% OF ACEH'S GDP.   PRIOR TO THE TSUNAMI HITTING THE SHORES OF ACEH, THIRTY YEARS OF VIOLENT CONFLICT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF INDONESIA (GOI) AND THE FREE ACEH MOVEMENT (GAM) HAD ALREADY DEVASTATED LARGE PARTS OF ACEH AND CLAIMED OVER 15,000 LIVES.   ON AUGUST 15TH, 2005, THE GOI AND THE GAM SIGNED A MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING (MOU) SIGNIFYING AN END TO THE BRUTAL CONFLICT. TO DATE, THE MOU HAS EXCEEDED EXPECTATIONS. MANY ANALYSTS BELIEVE THAT THE 2004 TSUNAMI ACTED AS A CATALYST TO ENCOURAGE THE CONFLICTING PARTIES TOWARDS PEACE.   THE GUBERNATORIAL AND DISTRICT ELECTIONS IN ACEH PROVINCE, INDONESIA, IN DECEMBER, WERE THE FIRST OF THEIR KIND, AND ARE A KEY ASPECT OF THE MOU. THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 2.6 MILLION ELIGIBLE ACEHNESSE VOTERS.   INDONESIA IS ONE OF CANADA'S KEY DEVELOPMENT PARTNERS, AND A MAJOR RECIPIENT OF TSUNAMI ASSISTANCE. IN RESPONSE TO THE TSUNAMI, CIDA APPROVED AND FULLY DISBURSED APPROXIMATELY $53 MILLION IN SHORT-TERM RELIEF PROJECTS FOR ACEH AND NIAS. CIDA ALSO PROVIDED $41.2 MILLION IN RESPONSE TO THE UN FLASH APPEAL, SOME OF WHICH WOULD HAVE BEEN DISBURSED IN INDONESIA. IN ORDER TO MEET THE LONG-TERM NEEDS OF TSUNAMI SURVIVORS, APPROXIMATELY $146 MILLION OF CANADA'S $425 MILLION PLEDGE WILL BE PROVIDED TO ACEH AND NIAS FOR RECONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES.   CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION ASSISTANCE TO ACEH AND NIAS IS GUIDED BY ITS RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY, WHICH WAS DESIGNED TO COMPLIMENT THE GOVERNMENT OF INDONESIA'S MASTER PLAN FOR RECONSTRUCTION. CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY FOR ACEH AND NIAS HAS TWO MAIN THRUSTS: (1) REBUILDING AND STRENGTHENING THE SYSTEM OF LOCAL GOVERNANCE AND (2) RESTORING LIVELIHOODS. IN ADDITION, THE RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY ENSURES THAT ENVIRONMENT, GENDER AND CONFLICT-SENSITIVITY ARE INCORPORATED AS CROSS-CUTTING THEMES. SINCE THE PROPOSED INITIATIVE SUPPORTS LOCAL GOVERNANCE IN THE FORM OF ELECTION SUPPORT, IT IS COMPLIMENTARY TO CIDA'S RECONSTRUCTION STRATEGY.EXPECTED IMPACT: A PERMANENTLY ESTABLISHED INDEPENDENT ELECTORAL MANAGEMENT BODY AND CONTINUED PEACE IN ACEH.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RECOGNIZED AND ACCEPTED ASSESSMENT OF THE ACEH 2006 LOCAL ELECTORAL PROCESSEXPECTED OUTPUTS: IMPROVED ABILITY OF ACEH CITIZENS, BOTH MEN AND WOMEN, TO PARTICIPATE IN ACEH'S 2006 LOCAL ELECTIONS IMPROVED ENABLING ENVIRONMENT FOR CIVIL SOCIETY TO HOLD POLITICAL ACTORS ACCOUNTABLE. project_title: Deepening democracy in Tanzania Program
long_description: Project Description: Deepening democracy in Tanzania Program NDP over three and a half years to support the implementation of the Deepening Democracy in Tanzania Program (DDTP). The program has the objective to support four broad strategic areas of democracy in Tanzania, namely: - Facilitation and implementation of the African Peer Review Mechanism (APRM) - The Elections Management Bodies and the Electoral Process - Civic Education - Good and Accountable Governance These broad strategic areas have been selected following extensive consultations with Government, civil society and development partners to determine priorities and also following the review of current activities of donor support and recommendations of the Independent Evaluation of the 2005 Elections Basket. The result of the DDTP will be to secure and expand democratic achievements to date by strengthening the capacity of democratic institutions, including Parliament, House of Representatives, the Election Management Bodies (National Electoral Commission and the Zanzibar Electoral Commission, civil society, media, and political parties. Countries: Tanzania,Un Rep (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance

project_title: Nepal Election Monitoring Mission - Nepal Election Monitoring mission
short_description: NEPAL ELECTION MONITORING MISSION - NEPAL ELECTION MONITORING MISSION
long_description: Project Description: Nepal Election Monitoring mission     Nepal is presently undergoing a period of intense political transition following the signing of the November 21, 2006 Comprehensive Peace Accord (CPA) between the recently reinstated Government of Nepal and the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist). It is planned that a Constituent Assembly (CA) election will take place in mid-2007.  There is a  need for an impartial international organization that is not directly involved in nor providing technical assistance to the process to independently monitor the transition surrounding the elections.  Such monitoring will help build confidence in the process and ensure that the election takes place in an environment free from fear, violence, or fraud.   The Carter Center proposes to address this need with a twelve-month project to monitor and assess the electoral and transitional process in Nepal to support the consolidation of peace and democracy in the country. Because the Center will not provide direct technical assistance to any of the stakeholders, it is uniquely positioned to carry out impartial monitoring and assessment activity in Nepal.  Where appropriate, based upon monitoring activities, the Center will draw upon President Carter's expertise and the Center's previous experience to provide informal advice on electoral and political issues.  The Center's activities will be complementary to and closely coordinated with that of the United Nations but will serve a distinctly separate function. The Center will also work closely with the EU and other international organizations. Expected Impact: To contribute to the democratic development and sustainable peace in Nepal.Expected Outcomes: 1.1  A well-run and transparent electoral process in an environment free from violence or fear of violence .2.1  Key leaders in Nepal have access to useful advice, guidance and support throughout the transition process and are able to successfully apply this to the process of conducting a high-quality Constituency  Assembly election. 3.1 Heightened awareness among Nepalis of in-ternational support for peace and democracy in their country. 4.1 Heightened awareness among Nepalis of in-ternational support for peace and democracy in their country. 5.1 A strengthened independent electoral management body. Expected Outputs: Ability of Nepal citizens, both men and women, to participate in Nepal's 2007 Constituent Assembly electionsCarter Centre election monitoring mission reportCountries: Nepal (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance

project_title: Election Support Program - Pakistan - Election Support Project - UNDP
short_description: ELECTION SUPPORT PROGRAM - PAKISTAN - ELECTION SUPPORT PROJECT - UNDP
long_description: Project Description: Election Support Program   UNDP   Working toward the goal of a free and fair election in Pakistan, and in coordination with other donors, the purpose of CIDA's support is to contribute to improved electoral administration and to a more informed and active electorate. Key activities will focus on strengthening  electoral  processes and civic education mechanisms, improving election coverage by the media, and building domestic monitoring capacity. Target beneficiaries will include women and youth (as new voters), journalists, religious leaders, and civil society organizations. Anticipated direct project partners will be The Asia Foundation Pakistan (under PK-033491-001)  and  the UNDP in Pakistan (under PK- 033491-002)  in close collaboration  with civil  society groups. Expected Impact: Post election stakeholder and voter surveys as well as civil society and media reporting indicates knowledge of election issues, an understanding of electoral and democratic processes, and of voter rights and obligations, especially in reference to women and youth. Low reported incidents of election irregularity, or voter intimidation, especially that of  women. No significant challenges to the accuracy of election results  with timely ratification of the results by the judiciary. International and domestic observers declare the Pakistan election freer and fairer than in previous trips to the polls. Expected Outcomes: Raised awareness, increased participation and active engagement of key election stakeholders in the democratic process including: women and youth; religious leaders, the Election Commission of Pakistan, civil society organizations, political parties and the media.   Increased confidence of the electorate in the fairness and transparency of the electoral process, and in the validity of election results. Expected Outputs: *1.  Voter and civic education programs and materials effectively developed with the capacity of organizations strengthened in program delivery. Increased capacity of ECP in the development of voter education plans and undertaking a voter education campaign Voter education source material developed Public awareness campaigns through mass media Voter education delivered through UNDP funding of civil society organizations *2.  Increase in voter registration and turnout especially that of women and youth and those in remote communities. Public awareness campaigns for voter registration Voter registration procedures and forms developed Trained registration staff Computerized voters rolls Trained ECP officials in use of voter rolls Research, data collection, analysis in support of GOP policies re:  voter registration /turnout  establishing electoral credibility *3.   Increased  election coverage by the media. Forums established for ECP/media interaction at the national and sub-national level Media briefings on electoral issues Materials developed for media awareness of election issues and of the electoralprocess. *4.   Modern Election Material (for all Polling Stations) Design,procurement and distribution of new ballot boxes Design,procurement and distribution of tamperproof transport bags Procurement and distribution of voting  screens for polling booths     Gender Equality Measures: Key areas of focus will be on  a)  security risks and mitigation measures to women voters turning out to vote, b) delivery of voter education to illiterate women, and c) measures to raise awareness and encourage men to support the participation of women in the electoral process.Countries: Pakistan (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development, Participatory Development, Gender Equality, Youth Issues

project_title: OSCE ELECTION OBSERVATION - SERBIA -001
long_description: PROJECT DESCRIPTION: OSCE ELECTION OBSERVATION - SERBIA -001   CIDA SUPPORTED THE DEPLOYMENT OF 2 CANADIAN LONG TERM OBSERVERS AND 5 SHORT TERM OBSERVERS TO THE ORGANIZATION FOR SECURITY AND COOPERATION IN EUROPE (OSCE)'S ELECTION OBSERVATION MISSION TO THE PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS OF SERBIA ON JANUARY 21ST, 2007. CANADIAN FUNDS WERE USED TO COVER THE LOGISTICS OF DEPLOYING THESE OBSERVERS. THE EXTENT OF THEIR ACTIVITES WAS TRAVELLING TO SERBIA, A SMALL AMOUNT OF TRAVELING WITHIN THE COUNTRY, AND RETURNING HOME. WHILE IN SERBIA, THESE OBSERVERS ASSESSED THE EXTENT TO WHICH THE ELECTION PROCESS TOOK PLACE IN ADHERENCE WITH DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL LAW. THEIR OBSERVATIONS CONTRIBUTED TO THE OSCE'S FINAL REPORT ON THE ELECTION.EXPECTED IMPACT: A PERMANENTLY ESTABLISHED INDEPENDENT ELECTORAL MANAGEMENT BODY.EXPECTED OUTCOMES: RECOGNIZED AND ACCEPTED ASSESSMENT OF THE SERBIAN 2007 PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS.EXPECTED OUTPUTS: IMPROVED ABILITY OF SERBIAN CITIZENS, BOTH MEN AND WOMEN, TO PARTICIPATE IN SERBIA'S 2007 PARLIAMENTARY ELECTIONS. IMPROVED ENABLING ENVIRONMENT FOR CIVIL SOCIETY TO HOLD POLITICAL ACTORS ACCOUNTABLE. AN INDEPENDENT AND IMPARTIAL OBSERVATION OF THE ELECTORAL PROCESS IN SERBIACOUNTRIES: SERBIAMONTENEGR (100%)  SECTORS: 015161 (100%)  THEMES: CANADA CORPS

project_title: Global Elections Organization Conference
long_description: Project Description: IFES will be holding The Global Electoral Organization (GEO) conference in Washington, D.C. on March 27-29, 2007.The conference aims to facilitate sharing good practices and lessons learned; to enable participants to share information, discover solutions to their electoral challenges, enhance the process of institutional learning on electoral matters, advance knowledge management in the governance field as well as establish professional relationships. The GEO conference contributes to overall capacity development of participating recipient countries. As the GEO Conference materials will be distributed in several languages, participants and those who get the materials following the conference will be able to share the results widely. Emerging and developing democracies will take home best practices and tools to aid in their efforts on election administration.Countries: Angola (2.3%), Albania (2.3%), Argentina (2.3%), Armenia (2.3%), Azerbaijan Rep (2.3%), Burundi (2.3%), Bosnia & Herz. (2.3%), Congo, Dem Rep. (2.3%), Côte d'Ivoire (2.3%), Cameroon (2.3%), Colombia (2.3%), Costa Rica (2.3%), Ecuador (2.3%), Georgia (2.3%), Ghana (2.3%), Guyana (2.3%), Honduras (2.3%), Croatia (2.3%), Haiti (2.3%), Indonesia (2.3%), Iraq (2.3%), Jamaica (2.3%), Jordan (2.3%), Kazakhstan Rep (2.3%), Kenya (2.3%), Kyrgyzstan (2.3%), Liberia (2.3%), Lesotho (2.3%), Moldova, Repub. (2.3%), Mexico (2.3%), Macedonia, Fr Y (2.3%), Nigeria (2.3%), Nicaragua (2.3%), Pakistan (2.3%), Panama (2.3%), Peru (2.3%), Sudan (2.3%), Senegal (2.3%), Sierra Leone (2.3%), El Salvador (2.3%), Ukraine (2.3%), Yemen (2.3%), South Africa (2.3%), Zambia (1.1%)  Sectors: 015161 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Knowledge Sharing and Networking, Capacity Development, Canada Corps

project_title: Support to Voter Education Election
long_description: UNDP has been a strong supporter of Indonesia's reforms in the field of democratic governance, particulary with regards to elections.  Based on the successful evaluation of UNDP's electoral support programme, CIDA is proposing to contribute to similar voter education activities for UNDP's electoral support programme for Election 2009.   Before the actual voter education campaigns are implemented, a needs assessment will be conducted on the current state of voters' education in Indonesia. The needs assessment team, made up of Government of Indonesia officials and members of civil society, will assess the results of the data collection, and produce a report that will contain a series of recommendations on technical, methodological, and programmatic approaches for the actual voter education activities to be conducted.   Subject to confirmation through the needs assessment, the voter education component will be delivered through the services of national and/or local civil society organizations and the media. Activities will include workshops, trainings, speaking campaigns, print and broadcast messaging, and indirect information campaigns (radio/TV broadcasts, posters, banners).   Throughout the project, UNDP will provide technical assistance support to the General Election Commission and the provincial election commissions in the areas considered most critical.  In addition, the project will provide technical assistance to civil society in the form of financial management, results-based reporting, etc.To ensure that democratic culture is promoted among targeted groups through voters education and awareness campaigns on democratic citizenshipExpected Outcomes: 1.  Voter education campaigns implemented for target groups (women/youth/poor)   2.  Enhanced involvement of women/youth/poor in decision-making at political levelsExpected Outputs: 1.1  General Election Commission lessons-learned to be applied to the execution of the present project. 1.2  Increased capacity of General Election Commission officials (national and provincial-level) to develop and implement future effective democratic voter education campaigns 2.1 Increased awareness on the part of target groups regarding the significance of elections and the role they play in their success 2.2 Increased levels of participation in the political process by target groups (women, youth, poor) 2.3 Increased capacity of civil society organizations to develop and implement effective voter education campaignsCountries: Indonesia (100%)  Sectors: 015161 (75%), 015150 (25%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development, Youth Issues

project_title: Strengthening Election Processes
long_description: The aim of this project is to assist in strengthening democratic electoral procedures and practices in Ukraine through the establishment and introduction of a unified state voter register, electoral legislation codification and increasing the level of professionalism of election officials in Ukraine as well as promoting wider participation of women and gender awareness during the electoral process. Accountability of select democratic governance institutions is improved. Electoral procedures and practices are standardized, transparent and unbiased.Expected Outcomes: 1.1 Complete, accurate, protected and regularly updated Central Voter Register is produced and contributes to the availability of sex-disaggregated statistics. 2.1 An Election Code that  strengthens and unifies electoral procedures and regulations and that provides for equal opportunities for women and men in electoral processes is submitted to Parliament for consideration. 3.1 Unified electoral procedures are applied and followed by election officials.Expected Outputs: 1.1 Subordinate legal acts necessary for the implementation of the February 2007 Law on the State Voter Register developed; 1.1.1 Amendments to relevant legal acts drafted to bring them into compliance with the Law on the State Voter Register e.g., criminal code of Ukraine and the code on administrative violations; 1.2  Equipment for the compilation of electronic voter list operationalized within the offices of CEC and RMBs across Ukraine; 1.3 CEC and RMB's personnel are able to effectively maintain and operate the state voter register. 2.1 Increased understanding and awareness among CEC members, and representatives of NGO's and political parties of international experiences on the conduct of elections and referenda in selected countries in Western and Eastern Europe; 2.2 Unified election code drafted, in a consultative manner and taking into account Ukrainian specifics and international commitments and recommendations, including those of the OSCE/ODIHR election observation reports and the Venice Commission; 2.3 Gender analysis of existing electoral legislation completed and integrated into the election code drafting process. 3.1 Gender sensitive training materials developed and films for district election commissioners and polling station commissioners produced; 3.2 Training of trainers completed and trainers certified based on test results; 3.3 Members of each polling station commission and district election commission trained.Countries: Ukraine (100%)  Sectors: 015140 (50%), 015161 (50%)  Themes: Good Governance

project_title: Afghan Elections support 2008-2010 - Afghan voter registration
short_description: AFGHAN ELECTIONS SUPPORT 2008-2010 - AFGHAN VOTER REGISTRATION
long_description: Afghan voter registration This component of the 2008-2010 Elections-support project  seeks to ensure  that the  Afghan Independent Elections Commission has the capacity to design and implement a sustainable national voter registration program. Therefore, Canada's first disbursement  to UNDP's elections basket-fund will go to supporting the voter registration process in Afghanistan. Voter registration  will commence in October 2008 and continue through to February 2009. Voter registration  will be conducted in four phases at over 600 district centres, uttilising multiple stations within centers and with mobile teams for Kuchis, armed forces, prisoners and IDPs. The registration exercise  will aim to capture all eligible voters currently residing in Afghanistan.  The voter registry process will focus on those who have not previously registered; have lost their voter's card or who will be 18 in time for the Presidential elections. Previously issued cards will remain valid. It is intended that the VR exercise will build a foundation for a viable long term voter registry; link new registrants to polling stations and provide for the introduction of Automatic Fingerprint  Identification System (AFIS) scanning for duplicates of new registrants.     Countries: Afghanistan TIS (100%)  Sectors: 015151 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development

project_title: Election Assistance Building
long_description: The goal of the project is to contribute to strengthened governance, democratization and stability in Malawi through the effective preparation and conduct of free, fair and credible Presidential and Parliamentary elections in May 2009 and beyond. The project's purpose is to strengthen the management and technical capacity of the Malawi Election Commission (MEC) to effectively conduct free, fair and credible elections, as well as to increase citizens' participation in exercising their democratic rights.   The project will accomplish these goals by focusing on three key areas leading up to the May 2009 elections: building the technical and management capacity of the Malawi Electoral Commission, voter registration and voter education.   The project does not contain activities in relation to physical work as defined in the CEAA. Consequently, an environmental assessment isnot required under the CEAA.Countries: Malawi (100%)  Sectors: 015151 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance

project_title: Strengthening Electoral Processes in Zam
long_description: The project aims to strengthen citizen engagement, electoral processes, and practices in line with CIDA's objectives in strengthening democratic governance.  The goal of the project is to support the Electoral Commission of Zambia (ECZ) and relevant government departments in their ability to prepare for and manage free and fair elections. More specifically, the project is working to: enhance the accuracy of the voter register; increase the ability of the National Voter Education Committee to coordinate, plan and implement continuous voter education; strengthen participation by women as candidates and strengthen organizational capacity of civil sociey organisations working in the area of women's political rights in Zambia; strengthen the ability of the Electoral Commission of Zambia to engage the media; and revise the legislative framework and code of conduct to ensure a viable and fair means of redress in the event of electoral malpractices. Countries: Zambia (100%)  Sectors: 015151 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development

project_title: Afghan Elections support 2008-2010 - Evaluation and capacity-building
short_description: AFGHAN ELECTIONS SUPPORT 2008-2010 - EVALUATION AND CAPACITY-BUILDING
long_description: Monitoring, evaluation, capcity building   This component of the Afghan Elections support 2008-2010 seeks to set aside CIDA ressources to support  the monitoring, evaluation and capacity building needs of the project.  Approval for this funding needs to be obtained at the early stages of the ELECT basket-fund, as it  will support activities throughout the project's life-cycle.  This funding  will contribute to various activities, including:   -Improving UNDP's Risks and Results-based-Management framework for Elections: As an active member of the elections donor group in Kabul, Canada has offered to provide UNDP with expertise to develop the results framework for Elections programming. For CIDA to provide this kind of RBM support would be consistent with the regular feedback it has been giving to UNDP regarding the need to improve results-reporting in CIDA-funded UNDP projects.   -DFID-led initial assessment of Elections basket-funding: The United Kingdom's DFID has said that it has the funds in place to quickly fund this initial assessment, which would put in place a recommendation for the composition of a basket fund towards election support. KABUL has expressed its will to support DFID in this assessment. Canadian support to the assessment would place Canada in a leadership role, positioning it as a key member of the ELECT project board committee.   This project component  will necessitate the deployment of expert s to Afghanistan, when possible.Countries: Afghanistan TIS (100%)  Sectors: 015151 (100%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development

project_title: Electoral Assistance for the Americas
long_description: This program is part of a key element of Canada's re-engagement in the Americas by supporting the Organization of American States (OAS) in its role as the hemisphere's multilateral forum to promote democratic governance and sustainable development. The OAS is a trusted CIDA partner that has extensive experience in monitoring various types of electoral processes.   This project aims to improve electoral processes in the Americas by supporting multilateral election observation missions. These missions serve to strengthen the institutions that guarantee transparency and effectiveness of elections, including electoral organization, administration, and spending. The project increases the ability of the OAS to rapidly deploy election observers, leading to increased voter confidence in the democratic processes and institutions of their country. In addition, this project allows for increased flexibility in electoral mission management and promotes multi-donor funding.   The project is part of the Multilateral Election Observation Program. This Program uses a whole-of-government approach for Canadian support to multilateral election observation in developing countries. Its main objective is to assist developing countries in their objective to hold democratic elections in line with national and international election standards. Support for election observation contributes to strengthening the electoral process in developing countries.Countries: Americas MC (100%)  Sectors: 015151 (50%), 015110 (30%), 015160 (20%)  Themes: Good Governance, Capacity Development

UNIFEM Kenya is the Prog.Fin.Management Agent.  Acitivities includes ways of strengthening women candidates in the run up to the general elections in 2007.

project_title: Election Support Programme
long_description: Tanzania will organice it's presidental, parliamentary and municipality elections in October 2010. UNDP, together with the government of Republic of Tanzania and it's development partners have developed an Elections Support Project (ESP) that is dedicated to strengthen the Electoral Management Bodies (EMBs) capasity to follow trough the elections independently and transparently. The ESP's main goal is to further strengthen national capabilities for the implementation of free, fair and credible elections, with support to the preparations, management and conduct of the elections. The focus is the strengthening of the national leadership of EMBs and engagement of political parties, media, and other civid society as well as national security management institututions in contributing to the overall goal and to prevent to post elections violence.

project_title: Afghan elections support basket fund / Fonds commun de support aux élections afghanes
short_description: AFGHAN ELECTIONS SUPPORT BASKET FUND / FONDS COMMUN DE SUPPORT AUX ÉLECTIONS AFGHANES
long_description: By working directly with the Afghan Independent Elections Commission (IEC), UNDP-ELECT offers the main vehicle through which Canada can support the core mechanisms of these elections, such as voter registration, recruitment and training of election officials, production and transportation of election materials, and verification of results, while respecting Afghan ownership over the electoral process. The programme will also support the creation of key bodies such as Electoral Complaints and Media Commissions, and key functions such as domestic observation and monitoring. In partnership with others, UNDP-ELECT will additionally support complementary programming on voter education and outreach, as well as media and police training. / En travaillant directement avec la Commission indépendante électorale afghane (IEC), le programme ELECT du PNUD est le véhicule principal à travers duquel le Canada soutiendra les mécanismes essentiels à la tenue des élections afghanes. Les activités de support incluent l'enregistrements des électeurs, le recrutement et la formation d'officiels électoraux, la production et la transportation du matériel électoral, ainsi que la vérification des résultats électoraux. Le programme supportera aussi la création d'institutions essentielles telles qu'une Commission de vérification des plaintes reliées aux élections, et une Commission médiatique. Le programme supportera également l'observation électorale domestique ainsi que l'évaluation et le suivi des résultats. En partenariat avec d'autres, ELECT financera l'éducation publique et la communication auprès des électeurs, ainsi que la formation des médias et de la police.

project_title: Joint Donor Training for Effective Electoral Assistance / Formation conjointe à l'intention des donateurs pour une assistance électorale efficace
short_description: JOINT DONOR TRAINING FOR EFFECTIVE ELECTORAL ASSISTANCE / FORMATION CONJOINTE À L'INTENTION DES DONATEURS POUR UNE ASSISTANCE ÉLECTORALE EFFICACE
long_description: This project, co-funded with other donor agencies, aims to improve the quality, coherence, and effectiveness of electoral assistance through joint training on the electoral cycle approach and best practices. Training is delivered to electoral management bodies and electoral assistance practitioners internationally, as well as to donor, development partner, and stakeholder staff members. Participants share experiences and develop a better understanding of the electoral cycle approach, thereby building capacity for the formulation and implementation of future electoral assistance initiatives. The project is part of the Multilateral Election Observation Program. This Program uses a whole-of-government approach for Canadian support to multilateral election observation in developing countries. Its main objective is to assist developing countries in their objective to hold democratic elections in line with national and international election standards. Support for election observation contributes to strengthening the electoral process in developing countries. / Cofinancé avec autres organismes donateurs, ce projet vise à améliorer la qualité, la cohérence et l'efficacité de l'assistance électorale au moyen de formation conjointe portant sur les meilleures pratiques et une approche axée sur le cycle électoral. Cette formation est donnée aux organismes de gestion électorale et aux praticiens de l'assistance électorale à l'échelle internationale ainsi qu'aux donateurs, aux partenaires d'exécution et aux employés des principaux intervenants. Les participants font part d'expériences et acquièrent une meilleure compréhension de l'approche axée sur le cycle électoral, ce qui renforce ainsi la capacité d'élaborer et de mettre en oeuvre de futures initiatives d'assistance électorale. Le projet s'inscrit dans le cadre du Programme multilatéral d'observation électorale, lequel emprunte une approche pangouvernementale pour fournir du soutien canadien aux missions multilatérales d'observation électorale dans les pays en développement. Son principal objectif est d'aider les pays en développement à tenir des élections démocratiques conforment aux normes électorales nationales et internationales. L'appui à l'observation électorale permet de renforcer le processus électoral dans les pays en développement.
